content: 1 The Song of Songs, that is Solomon’s.
content_old: 1 The Song of Songs, that is Solomon’s.

content: 2 Let him kiss me with kisses of his mouth, For better are thy loves than wine.
content_old: 2 Let him kiss me with kisses of his mouth, For better are thy loves than wine.

content: 3 For fragrance are thy perfumes good. Perfume emptied out—thy name, Therefore have virgins loved thee!
content_old: 3 For fragrance are thy perfumes good. Perfume emptied out—thy name, Therefore have virgins loved thee!

content: 4 Draw me: after thee we run, The king hath brought me into his inner chambers, We do joy and rejoice in thee, We mention thy loves more than wine, Uprightly they have loved thee!
content_old: 4 Draw me: after thee we run, The king hath brought me into his inner chambers, We do joy and rejoice in thee, We mention thy loves more than wine, Uprightly they have loved thee!

content: 5 Dark am I, and comely, daughters of Jerusalem, As tents of Kedar, as curtains of Solomon.
content_old: 5 Dark am I, and comely, daughters of Jerusalem, As tents of Kedar, as curtains of Solomon.

content: 6 Fear me not, because I am very dark, Because the sun hath scorched me, The sons of my mother were angry with me, They made me keeper of the vineyards, My vineyard—my own—I have not kept.
content_old: 6 Fear me not, because I am very dark, Because the sun hath scorched me, The sons of my mother were angry with me, They made me keeper of the vineyards, My vineyard—my own—I have not kept.

content: 7 Declare to me, thou whom my soul hath loved, Where thou delightest, Where thou liest down at noon, For why am I as one veiled, By the ranks of thy companions?
content_old: 7 Declare to me, thou whom my soul hath loved, Where thou delightest, Where thou liest down at noon, For why am I as one veiled, By the ranks of thy companions?

content: 8 If thou knowest not, O fair among women, Get thee forth by the traces of the flock, And feed thy kids by the shepherds’ dwellings!
content_old: 8 If thou knowest not, O fair among women, Get thee forth by the traces of the flock, And feed thy kids by the shepherds’ dwellings!

content: 9 To my joyous one in chariots of Pharaoh, I have compared thee, my friend,
content_old: 9 To my joyous one in chariots of Pharaoh, I have compared thee, my friend,

content: 10 Comely have been thy cheeks with garlands, Thy neck with chains.
content_old: 10 Comely have been thy cheeks with garlands, Thy neck with chains.

content: 11 Garlands of gold we do make for thee, With studs of silver!
content_old: 11 Garlands of gold we do make for thee, With studs of silver!

content: 12 While the king is in his circle, My spikenard hath given its fragrance.
content_old: 12 While the king is in his circle, My spikenard hath given its fragrance.

content: 13 A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me, Between my breasts it lodgeth.
content_old: 13 A bundle of myrrh is my beloved to me, Between my breasts it lodgeth.

content: 14 A cluster of cypress is my beloved to me, In the vineyards of En-Gedi!
content_old: 14 A cluster of cypress is my beloved to me, In the vineyards of En-Gedi!

content: 15 Lo, thou art fair, my friend, Lo, thou art fair, thine eyes are doves!
content_old: 15 Lo, thou art fair, my friend, Lo, thou art fair, thine eyes are doves!

content: 16 Lo, thou art fair, my love, yea, pleasant, Yea, our couch is green,
content_old: 16 Lo, thou art fair, my love, yea, pleasant, Yea, our couch is green,

content: 1 As a lily among the thorns,
content_old: 1 As a lily among the thorns,

content: 2 So is my friend among the daughters!
content_old: 2 So is my friend among the daughters!

content: 3 As a citron among trees of the forest, So is my beloved among the sons, In his shade I delighted, and sat down, And his fruit is sweet to my palate.
content_old: 3 As a citron among trees of the forest, So is my beloved among the sons, In his shade I delighted, and sat down, And his fruit is sweet to my palate.

content: 4 He hath brought me in unto a house of wine, And his banner over me is love,
content_old: 4 He hath brought me in unto a house of wine, And his banner over me is love,

content: 5 Sustain me with grape-cakes, Support me with citrons, for I am sick with love.
content_old: 5 Sustain me with grape-cakes, Support me with citrons, for I am sick with love.

content: 6 His left hand is under my head, And his right doth embrace me.
content_old: 6 His left hand is under my head, And his right doth embrace me.

content: 7 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!
content_old: 7 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!

content: 8 The voice of my beloved! lo, this—he is coming, Leaping on the mountains, skipping on the hills.
content_old: 8 The voice of my beloved! lo, this—he is coming, Leaping on the mountains, skipping on the hills.

content: 9 My beloved is like to a roe, Or to a young one of the harts. Lo, this—he is standing behind our wall, Looking from the windows, Blooming from the lattice.
content_old: 9 My beloved is like to a roe, Or to a young one of the harts. Lo, this—he is standing behind our wall, Looking from the windows, Blooming from the lattice.

content: 10 My beloved hath answered and said to me, ‘Rise up, my friend, my fair one, and come away,
content_old: 10 My beloved hath answered and said to me, ‘Rise up, my friend, my fair one, and come away,

content: 11 For lo, the winter hath passed by, The rain hath passed away—it hath gone.
content_old: 11 For lo, the winter hath passed by, The rain hath passed away—it hath gone.

content: 12 The flowers have appeared in the earth, The time of the singing hath come, And the voice of the turtle was heard in our land,
content_old: 12 The flowers have appeared in the earth, The time of the singing hath come, And the voice of the turtle was heard in our land,

content: 13 The fig-tree hath ripened her green figs, And the sweet-smelling vines have given forth fragrance, Rise, come, my friend, my fair one, yea, come away.
content_old: 13 The fig-tree hath ripened her green figs, And the sweet-smelling vines have given forth fragrance, Rise, come, my friend, my fair one, yea, come away.

content: 14 My dove, in clefts of the rock, In a secret place of the ascent, Cause me to see thine appearance, Cause me to hear thy voice, For thy voice is sweet, and thy appearance comely.
content_old: 14 My dove, in clefts of the rock, In a secret place of the ascent, Cause me to see thine appearance, Cause me to hear thy voice, For thy voice is sweet, and thy appearance comely.

content: 15 Seize ye for us foxes, Little foxes—destroyers of vineyards, Even our sweet-smelling vineyards.
content_old: 15 Seize ye for us foxes, Little foxes—destroyers of vineyards, Even our sweet-smelling vineyards.

content: 16 My beloved is mine, and I am his, Who is delighting among the lilies,
content_old: 16 My beloved is mine, and I am his, Who is delighting among the lilies,

content: 1 On my couch by night, I sought him whom my soul hath loved; I sought him, and I found him not!
content_old: 1 On my couch by night, I sought him whom my soul hath loved; I sought him, and I found him not!

content: 2 —Pray, let me rise, and go round the city, In the streets and in the broad places, I seek him whom my soul hath loved!—I sought him, and I found him not.
content_old: 2 —Pray, let me rise, and go round the city, In the streets and in the broad places, I seek him whom my soul hath loved!—I sought him, and I found him not.

content: 3 The watchmen have found me, (Who are going round about the city), ‘Him whom my soul have loved saw ye?’
content_old: 3 The watchmen have found me, (Who are going round about the city), ‘Him whom my soul have loved saw ye?’

content: 4 But a little I passed on from them, Till I found him whom my soul hath loved! I seized him, and let him not go, Till I brought him in unto the house of my mother—And the chamber of her that conceived me.
content_old: 4 But a little I passed on from them, Till I found him whom my soul hath loved! I seized him, and let him not go, Till I brought him in unto the house of my mother—And the chamber of her that conceived me.

content: 5 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!
content_old: 5 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, By the roes or by the hinds of the field, Stir not up nor wake the love till she please!

content: 6 Who is this coming up from the wilderness, Like palm-trees of smoke, Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, From every powder of the merchant?
content_old: 6 Who is this coming up from the wilderness, Like palm-trees of smoke, Perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, From every powder of the merchant?

content: 7 Lo, his couch, that is Solomon’s, Sixty mighty ones are around it, Of the mighty of Israel,
content_old: 7 Lo, his couch, that is Solomon’s, Sixty mighty ones are around it, Of the mighty of Israel,

content: 8 All of them holding sword, taught of battle, Each his sword by his thigh, for fear at night.
content_old: 8 All of them holding sword, taught of battle, Each his sword by his thigh, for fear at night.

content: 9 A palanquin king Solomon made for himself, Of the wood of Lebanon,
content_old: 9 A palanquin king Solomon made for himself, Of the wood of Lebanon,

content: 10 Its pillars he made of silver, Its bottom of gold, its seat of purple, Its midst lined with love, By the daughters of Jerusalem.
content_old: 10 Its pillars he made of silver, Its bottom of gold, its seat of purple, Its midst lined with love, By the daughters of Jerusalem.

content: 1 Lo, thou art fair, my friend, lo, thou art fair, Thine eyes are doves behind thy veil, Thy hair as a row of the goats That have shone from mount Gilead,
content_old: 1 Lo, thou art fair, my friend, lo, thou art fair, Thine eyes are doves behind thy veil, Thy hair as a row of the goats That have shone from mount Gilead,

content: 2 Thy teeth as a row of the shorn ones That have come up from the washing, For all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.
content_old: 2 Thy teeth as a row of the shorn ones That have come up from the washing, For all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.

content: 3 As a thread of scarlet are thy lips, And thy speech is comely, As the work of the pomegranate is thy temple behind thy veil,
content_old: 3 As a thread of scarlet are thy lips, And thy speech is comely, As the work of the pomegranate is thy temple behind thy veil,

content: 4 As the tower of David is thy neck, built for an armoury, The chief of the shields are hung on it, All shields of the mighty.
content_old: 4 As the tower of David is thy neck, built for an armoury, The chief of the shields are hung on it, All shields of the mighty.

content: 5 Thy two breasts are as two fawns, Twins of a roe, that are feeding among lilies.
content_old: 5 Thy two breasts are as two fawns, Twins of a roe, that are feeding among lilies.

content: 6 Till the day doth break forth, And the shadows have fled away, I will get me unto the mountain of myrrh, And unto the hill of frankincense.
content_old: 6 Till the day doth break forth, And the shadows have fled away, I will get me unto the mountain of myrrh, And unto the hill of frankincense.

content: 7 Thou art all fair, my friend, And a blemish there is not in thee. Come from Lebanon, O spouse,
content_old: 7 Thou art all fair, my friend, And a blemish there is not in thee. Come from Lebanon, O spouse,

content: 8 Come from Lebanon, come thou in. Look from the top of Amana, From the top of Shenir and Hermon, From the habitations of lions, From the mountains of leopards.
content_old: 8 Come from Lebanon, come thou in. Look from the top of Amana, From the top of Shenir and Hermon, From the habitations of lions, From the mountains of leopards.

content: 9 Thou hast emboldened me, my sister-spouse, Emboldened me with one of thine eyes, With one chain of thy neck.
content_old: 9 Thou hast emboldened me, my sister-spouse, Emboldened me with one of thine eyes, With one chain of thy neck.

content: 10 How wonderful have been thy loves, my sister-spouse, How much better have been thy loves than wine, And the fragrance of thy perfumes than all spices.
content_old: 10 How wonderful have been thy loves, my sister-spouse, How much better have been thy loves than wine, And the fragrance of thy perfumes than all spices.

content: 11 Thy lips drop honey, O spouse, Honey and milk are under thy tongue, And the fragrance of thy garments Is as the fragrance of Lebanon.
content_old: 11 Thy lips drop honey, O spouse, Honey and milk are under thy tongue, And the fragrance of thy garments Is as the fragrance of Lebanon.

content: 12 A garden shut up is my sister-spouse, A spring shut up—a fountain sealed.
content_old: 12 A garden shut up is my sister-spouse, A spring shut up—a fountain sealed.

content: 13 Thy shoots a paradise of pomegranates, With precious fruits,
content_old: 13 Thy shoots a paradise of pomegranates, With precious fruits,

content: 14 Cypresses with nard—nard and saffron, Cane and cinnamon, With all trees of frankincense, Myrrh and aloes, with all chief spices.
content_old: 14 Cypresses with nard—nard and saffron, Cane and cinnamon, With all trees of frankincense, Myrrh and aloes, with all chief spices.

content: 15 A fount of gardens, a well of living waters, And flowings from Lebanon!
content_old: 15 A fount of gardens, a well of living waters, And flowings from Lebanon!

content: 1 I have come in to my garden, my sister-spouse, I have plucked my myrrh with my spice, I have eaten my comb with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends, drink, Yea, drink abundantly, O beloved ones!
content_old: 1 I have come in to my garden, my sister-spouse, I have plucked my myrrh with my spice, I have eaten my comb with my honey, I have drunk my wine with my milk. Eat, O friends, drink, Yea, drink abundantly, O beloved ones!

content: 2 I am sleeping, but my heart waketh: The sound of my beloved knocking! ‘Open to me, my sister, my friend, My dove, my perfect one, For my head is filled with dew, My locks with drops of the night.’
content_old: 2 I am sleeping, but my heart waketh: The sound of my beloved knocking! ‘Open to me, my sister, my friend, My dove, my perfect one, For my head is filled with dew, My locks with drops of the night.’

content: 3 I have put off my coat, how do I put it on? I have washed my feet, how do I defile them?
content_old: 3 I have put off my coat, how do I put it on? I have washed my feet, how do I defile them?

content: 4 My beloved sent his hand from the net-work, And my bowels were moved for him.
content_old: 4 My beloved sent his hand from the net-work, And my bowels were moved for him.

content: 5 I rose to open to my beloved, And my hands dropped myrrh, Yea, my fingers flowing myrrh, On the handles of the lock.
content_old: 5 I rose to open to my beloved, And my hands dropped myrrh, Yea, my fingers flowing myrrh, On the handles of the lock.

content: 6 I opened to my beloved, But my beloved withdrew—he passed on, My soul went forth when he spake, I sought him, and found him not. I called him, and he answered me not.
content_old: 6 I opened to my beloved, But my beloved withdrew—he passed on, My soul went forth when he spake, I sought him, and found him not. I called him, and he answered me not.

content: 7 The watchmen who go round about the city, Found me, smote me, wounded me, Keepers of the walls lifted up my veil from off me.
content_old: 7 The watchmen who go round about the city, Found me, smote me, wounded me, Keepers of the walls lifted up my veil from off me.

content: 8 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, If ye find my beloved—What do ye tell him? that I am sick with love!
content_old: 8 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, If ye find my beloved—What do ye tell him? that I am sick with love!

content: 9 What is thy beloved above any beloved, O fair among women? What is thy beloved above any beloved, That thus thou hast adjured us?
content_old: 9 What is thy beloved above any beloved, O fair among women? What is thy beloved above any beloved, That thus thou hast adjured us?

content: 10 My beloved is clear and ruddy, Conspicuous above a myriad!
content_old: 10 My beloved is clear and ruddy, Conspicuous above a myriad!

content: 11 His head is pure gold—fine gold, His locks flowing, dark as a raven,
content_old: 11 His head is pure gold—fine gold, His locks flowing, dark as a raven,

content: 12 His eyes as doves by streams of water, Washing in milk, sitting in fulness.
content_old: 12 His eyes as doves by streams of water, Washing in milk, sitting in fulness.

content: 13 His cheeks as a bed of the spice, towers of perfumes, His lips are lilies, dropping flowing myrrh,
content_old: 13 His cheeks as a bed of the spice, towers of perfumes, His lips are lilies, dropping flowing myrrh,

content: 14 His hands rings of gold, set with beryl, His heart bright ivory, covered with sapphires,
content_old: 14 His hands rings of gold, set with beryl, His heart bright ivory, covered with sapphires,

content: 15 His limbs pillars of marble, Founded on sockets of fine gold, His appearance as Lebanon, choice as the cedars.
content_old: 15 His limbs pillars of marble, Founded on sockets of fine gold, His appearance as Lebanon, choice as the cedars.

content: 1 Whither hath thy beloved gone, O fair among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned, And we seek him with thee?
content_old: 1 Whither hath thy beloved gone, O fair among women? Whither hath thy beloved turned, And we seek him with thee?

content: 2 My beloved went down to his garden, To the beds of the spice, To delight himself in the gardens, and to gather lilies.
content_old: 2 My beloved went down to his garden, To the beds of the spice, To delight himself in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

content: 3 I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine, Who is delighting himself among the lilies.
content_old: 3 I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine, Who is delighting himself among the lilies.

content: 4 Fair art thou, my friend, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts.
content_old: 4 Fair art thou, my friend, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts.

content: 5 Turn round thine eyes from before me, Because they have made me proud. Thy hair is as a row of the goats, That have shone from Gilead,
content_old: 5 Turn round thine eyes from before me, Because they have made me proud. Thy hair is as a row of the goats, That have shone from Gilead,

content: 6 Thy teeth as a row of the lambs, That have come up from the washing, Because all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.
content_old: 6 Thy teeth as a row of the lambs, That have come up from the washing, Because all of them are forming twins, And a bereaved one is not among them.

content: 7 As the work of the pomegranate is thy temple behind thy veil.
content_old: 7 As the work of the pomegranate is thy temple behind thy veil.

content: 8 Sixty are queens, and eighty concubines, And virgins without number.
content_old: 8 Sixty are queens, and eighty concubines, And virgins without number.

content: 9 One is my dove, my perfect one, One she is of her mother, The choice one she is of her that bare her, Daughters saw, and pronounce her happy, Queens and concubines, and they praise her.
content_old: 9 One is my dove, my perfect one, One she is of her mother, The choice one she is of her that bare her, Daughters saw, and pronounce her happy, Queens and concubines, and they praise her.

content: 10 ‘Who is this that is looking forth as morning, Fair as the moon—clear as the sun, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts?’
content_old: 10 ‘Who is this that is looking forth as morning, Fair as the moon—clear as the sun, Awe-inspiring as bannered hosts?’

content: 11 Unto a garden of nuts I went down, To look on the buds of the valley, To see whither the vine had flourished, The pomegranates had blossomed—
content_old: 11 Unto a garden of nuts I went down, To look on the buds of the valley, To see whither the vine had flourished, The pomegranates had blossomed—

content: 12 I knew not my soul, It made me—chariots of my people Nadib.
content_old: 12 I knew not my soul, It made me—chariots of my people Nadib.

content: 1 As the chorus of ‘Mahanaim.’ How beautiful were thy feet with sandals, O daughter of Nadib. The turnings of thy sides are as ornaments, Work of the hands of an artificer.
content_old: 1 As the chorus of ‘Mahanaim.’ How beautiful were thy feet with sandals, O daughter of Nadib. The turnings of thy sides are as ornaments, Work of the hands of an artificer.

content: 2 Thy waist is a basin of roundness, It lacketh not the mixture, Thy body a heap of wheat, fenced with lilies,
content_old: 2 Thy waist is a basin of roundness, It lacketh not the mixture, Thy body a heap of wheat, fenced with lilies,

content: 3 Thy two breasts as two young ones, twins of a roe,
content_old: 3 Thy two breasts as two young ones, twins of a roe,

content: 4 Thy neck as a tower of the ivory, Thine eyes pools in Heshbon, near the gate of Bath-Rabbim, Thy face as a tower of Lebanon looking to Damascus,
content_old: 4 Thy neck as a tower of the ivory, Thine eyes pools in Heshbon, near the gate of Bath-Rabbim, Thy face as a tower of Lebanon looking to Damascus,

content: 5 Thy head upon thee as Carmel, And the locks of thy head as purple, The king is bound with the flowings!
content_old: 5 Thy head upon thee as Carmel, And the locks of thy head as purple, The king is bound with the flowings!

content: 6 How fair and how pleasant hast thou been, O love, in delights.
content_old: 6 How fair and how pleasant hast thou been, O love, in delights.

content: 7 This thy stature hath been like to a palm, And thy breasts to clusters.
content_old: 7 This thy stature hath been like to a palm, And thy breasts to clusters.

content: 8 I said, ‘Let me go up on the palm, Let me lay hold on its boughs, Yea, let thy breasts be, I pray thee, as clusters of the vine, And the fragrance of thy face as citrons,
content_old: 8 I said, ‘Let me go up on the palm, Let me lay hold on its boughs, Yea, let thy breasts be, I pray thee, as clusters of the vine, And the fragrance of thy face as citrons,

content: 9 And thy palate as the good wine—’Flowing to my beloved in uprightness, Strengthening the lips of the aged!
content_old: 9 And thy palate as the good wine—’Flowing to my beloved in uprightness, Strengthening the lips of the aged!

content: 10 I am my beloved’s, and on me is his desire.
content_old: 10 I am my beloved’s, and on me is his desire.

content: 11 Come, my beloved, we go forth to the field,
content_old: 11 Come, my beloved, we go forth to the field,

content: 12 We lodge in the villages, we go early to the vineyards, We see if the vine hath flourished, The sweet smelling-flower hath opened. The pomegranates have blossomed, There do I give to thee my loves;
content_old: 12 We lodge in the villages, we go early to the vineyards, We see if the vine hath flourished, The sweet smelling-flower hath opened. The pomegranates have blossomed, There do I give to thee my loves;

content: 1 Who doth make thee as a brother to me, Sucking the breasts of my mother? I find thee without, I kiss thee, Yea, they do not despise me,
content_old: 1 Who doth make thee as a brother to me, Sucking the breasts of my mother? I find thee without, I kiss thee, Yea, they do not despise me,

content: 2 I lead thee, I bring thee in unto my mother’s house, She doth teach me, I cause thee to drink of the perfumed wine, Of the juice of my pomegranate,
content_old: 2 I lead thee, I bring thee in unto my mother’s house, She doth teach me, I cause thee to drink of the perfumed wine, Of the juice of my pomegranate,

content: 3 His left hand is under my head, And his right doth embrace me.
content_old: 3 His left hand is under my head, And his right doth embrace me.

content: 4 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, How ye stir up, And how ye wake the love till she please!
content_old: 4 I have adjured you, daughters of Jerusalem, How ye stir up, And how ye wake the love till she please!

content: 5 Who is this coming from the wilderness, Hasting herself for her beloved? Under the citron-tree I have waked thee, There did thy mother pledge thee, There she gave a pledge that bare thee.
content_old: 5 Who is this coming from the wilderness, Hasting herself for her beloved? Under the citron-tree I have waked thee, There did thy mother pledge thee, There she gave a pledge that bare thee.

content: 6 Set me as a seal on thy heart, as a seal on thine arm, For strong as death is love, Sharp as Sheol is jealousy, Its burnings are burnings of fire, a flame of Jah!
content_old: 6 Set me as a seal on thy heart, as a seal on thine arm, For strong as death is love, Sharp as Sheol is jealousy, Its burnings are burnings of fire, a flame of Jah!

content: 7 Many waters are not able to quench the love, And floods do not wash it away. If one give all the wealth of his house for love, Treading down—they tread upon it.
content_old: 7 Many waters are not able to quench the love, And floods do not wash it away. If one give all the wealth of his house for love, Treading down—they tread upon it.

content: 8 We have a little sister, and breasts she hath not, What do we do for our sister, In the day that it is told of her?
content_old: 8 We have a little sister, and breasts she hath not, What do we do for our sister, In the day that it is told of her?

content: 9 If she is a wall, we build by her a palace of silver. And if she is a door, We fashion by her board-work of cedar.
content_old: 9 If she is a wall, we build by her a palace of silver. And if she is a door, We fashion by her board-work of cedar.

content: 10 I am a wall, and my breasts as towers, Then I have been in his eyes as one finding peace.
content_old: 10 I am a wall, and my breasts as towers, Then I have been in his eyes as one finding peace.

content: 11 Solomon hath a vineyard in Baal-Hamon, He hath given the vineyard to keepers, Each bringeth for its fruit a thousand silverlings;
content_old: 11 Solomon hath a vineyard in Baal-Hamon, He hath given the vineyard to keepers, Each bringeth for its fruit a thousand silverlings;

content: 12 My vineyard—my own—is before me, The thousand is for thee, O Solomon. And the two hundred for those keeping its fruit. O dweller in gardens!
content_old: 12 My vineyard—my own—is before me, The thousand is for thee, O Solomon. And the two hundred for those keeping its fruit. O dweller in gardens!

content: 13 The companions are attending to thy voice, Cause me to hear. Flee, my beloved, and be like to a roe,
content_old: 13 The companions are attending to thy voice, Cause me to hear. Flee, my beloved, and be like to a roe,
